abstract.para: This file provides documentation for file 92BOMOGR.DAT, an ASCII file that contains bryophyte growth data from the Kuparuk River. We measured growth of Hygrohypnum spp. and Fontinalis neomexicana clumps and stem tips in control and fertilized (PO4 phosphorus), pools and riffles.

para.literalLayout: In 1990 we observed increased abundance's of several species of aquatic bryophytes in the fertilized zone of the Kuparuk River relative to the control. These bryophytes included, most notably, two species of Hygrohypnum, H. alpestre and H. ochraceum, and, to a lesser extent, Fontinalis neomexicana, Schistidium agassizii and the leafy liverwort Solenostoma spp.. Bryophyte biomass collections from random quadrants in control and phosphorus-enriched zones of the Kuparuk River in 1990 and 1991 indicated that there were 17+9 g dry mass per meter squared in the control zone and 322+96 g in the enriched zone (+/-SE, N = 5). We utilized point transects in 1992 and 1993 to estimate bryophyte coverage in the enriched and control zones (see 92BOMOPT AND 93BOMOPT .DOC AND .DAT). These data suggested that the increase in bryophyte biomass was confined to fertilized riffles of the river. To substantiate these data, we examined bryophyte growth in the river using clumps and stem tips of Hygrohypnum spp. and F. neomexicana transplanted from fertilized riffles to control and fertilized, pools and riffles. We affixed bryophyte clumps (0.5 to 1.5 g initial weight, towel- dried) and tips (3 to 7 cm long) to wooden boards with Velcro strips and staked them to the stream bottom so the bryophytes were exposed to a natural flow regime. Clumps were not placed in pools in 1992. All bryophytes were initially free of visible detritus and periphyton. Bryophytes were placed in the stream 7 July, and were collected and re-weighed and re-measured on 8 August (after 32 days). Clump weights were initially unequal so changes in weight were expressed as percent change from initial values. Tip elongation was expressed as an absolute change from the initial tip length.
